cab.content: this Document is the'3 Drttaimfa Mafrafc 63*^^. . JO 423MINISTRY OF POOD.^J^lI^^" for Week end in Wednesday, April 2, 1919. PART I. ACTION TAKEN. Food Council. Mr. A. E. Towle, Assistant Secretary in charge of the Fish, Fruit and Vegetables Division, has been appointed a member of the Council. The Council met on March 27th and April 1st. '., Memoranda on the arrangements already made and proposed for relinquishing control of all commodities dealt with by the Ministry of Food were considered. It was agreed that a statement on the subject should be sent to the Cabinet; which should be based upon these memoranda, and should set out the proposals of the Food Controller for bringing the Ministry of Food to an end, and for transferring to other Departments such of its functions as it is considered should still be exercised. A memoraudum submitted by the Royal Commission on Wheat Supplies on the decontrol of cereals, which is given in another part of this Report, was formally approved. As regards butter, it was decided that in view both of the very large expense which would be involved and of the fact that ample supplies of margarine were available, the" Council could not accept the recommendation of the Consumers' Council that the registration of customers should continue for an indefinite period. It was accordingly agreed that the use of coupons should cease at the beginning of May with the currency of the Ration Book, the system of registration with free exchange of retailers being retained till J une 30th. . It was reported that the supply and distribution of- imported meat would be freed from control on June 30th, but maximum prices would be retained until September 30th; and that control of home-produced meat would cease on the latter date. The Council were informed that the only foodstuffs which could be affected by the decontrol of the American exchange were bacon, lard and condensed milk ; but that there was at present no prospect that the necessary supplies could not be imported. The Ministry has arranged, with the assistance of Sir Hardman Lever, to keep in close touch with the situation. Imports Board. The following- statement shows the position of purchases, ship- ments and arrivals for the week ended March 22nd : Feeding Stuffs.-Shipments have been satisfactory except from India and Burmah. The actual quantities loaded during the week were as follows :- . ... ,. . .. ; r., . . . ;, , Tons. Decorticated cotton cake and meal (Brazil) - - - - 1,700 Linseed cake (United States of America) - - - 3,200 Rice, meal and ground nut cake (India and Burmah) - - 200 Cake (Egypt) - - - - - - - - - 3,500 Butter. The purchase of Argentine butter for the months September 1918 to March. 1919 will show a small excess over the estimated yield of 11,000 tons. There will be a substantial exportable surplus available this year from Denmark, part of which the Danish Government are anxious to send to the United Kingdom. Inquiries as to price and conditions of delivery are now being made. Similar inquiries are being undertaken in Holland where it is understood that the Government hold a reserve of some 3,000 tons which they may be prepared to sell. There is further a balance of 1,200 tons of the butter allotted to the United Kingdom by the United States Food Administration for which contracts have not yet been made/ The authority of H.M. Treasury for sanction to purchase this quantity is being requested. Recent shipments of butter have been good. Condensed Milk. The balance to be shipped from the United States on March 22nd was 2,000 to 3,000 tons. The last general distribution to the trade tpok place on April 1st. A (33)7792-1 Pklt! 150 4/lV K&S J : Dried Fruits.-^-Tha;last shipment-of Basra dates (5,000 tons) lias. -been.' v made, and the only outstanding purchases of dried fruits on the part of the Ministry are 3,000 tons from North America, ' Linseed.--Shipments from Uruguay, and India have been completed. There have been no shipments for several weeks from, the Argentine, where the balance is over 34,000 tons. It may be necessary to arrange for the sale of this balance either to Germany'or in the Argentine. Labour Conference. The Tenth Labour Conference was held at the New County Hall on March 29th, Sir William Beveridge being in the chair. The following were the principal resolutions passed : (a) With a view to increasing the home supply of foodstuffs and the consequent lowering of prices, the meeting urges the Board of Agriculture and the Ministries of Food and National Service, at once to take co-ordinating steps to acquire large areas of land for the purpose of cultivation by discharged soldiers and sailors who may desire to be so occupied, any such scheme to be provided for by assistance from the State; and further, this meeting is of the opinion that the steps taken in this ' - direction by the Government are insufficient to meet the requirements of the position. ' (b) The meeting demands that the Government publish immediately the information recently obtained regarding the starving condition of the people of Eastern and Central Europe, and urges that the dictates of humanity and common sense demand that immediate steps be taken to relieve the needs of these peoples. ROYAL COMMISSION ON THE SUGAR SUPPLY. Lord Bledisloe has resigned his positions as Chairman of the Royal Commissionon the Sugar Supply and Director of Sugar Distribution at the Ministry of Food.Lord Bledisloe was Parliamentary Secretary to the Ministry of Food until ill-healthcaused his retirement. He succeeded Lord Devonport as Chairman of the RoyalCommission and his work has proved a conspicuous success. - Speaking at a dinner of the National Sugar ,Confectionery and ChocolateConvention on April 2nd, Lord Bledisloe said that the control of sugar had becomeeasier every day, and so far as the ordinary domestic consumer was concerned wasabout to be relaxed to such an extent that he hoped it would hardly be felt at all.But it would not be in the interests of that industry or of the general public thatsugar control should be relaxed altogether at the present time. There was a'world- shortage of sugar, and there was no present prospect of a fall in the world price or indeed of an increased supply for some time to come. The temporary shortage of white sugar was likely to continue for some time.He would not be so rash as to say that there would be even sufficient white sugarfor the requirements of jam making, but he did not think that private fruit growersneed feel doleful. Without the intricate machinery set up last year they should be able to obtain as large supplies as they had last year, and there might be somethingavailable for those who did not grow fruit themselves but were in the habit of preserving fruit purchased from others. In those countries where sugar was normallylargely produced, especially Germany, there was no doubt that a considerable area. which would normally be occupied with the beet sugar crop, would during the nextfew years be occupied with the production of breadstuffs. The f.o.b, price of Java sugar had more than trebled during the last eight or nine months, and unless wewere careful in years to come, so great was the increased production of cane sugar in neutral countries that there would be a great temptation for countries like Cuba and Java to create something like a corner. When Germany could export sugar it would undoubtedly be absorbed into the general consumption throughout the world, andwould to that extent ease the sugar position: He could not say how long the SugarControl was likely to last. It was certain to last until the late autumn, probably tothe end of the year, or even longer. ; : ' DECONTROL OF CEREALS......? - The Royal Commission on. Wheat Supplies is anxious to' bring about decontrolas soon as possible, but it is hampered in its efforts,"probSblyJto a/greater degree than any other supply division, by Tuter-Ailied obligations. Some progress lias,however, already been made, and it is expected that it will be possible to extend and.accelerate decontrol in the near future. . ,. On December 4th, 1918, all restrictions on importation and trading in the UnitedKingdom were removed in respect of a large number of articles, viz., starches, glucose,dextrines, farina, tapioca, sago, manioc, cassava., mandioca, arrowroot, potato flour,macaroni and all such like products. All restrictions on the use of barby, dredgecorn, maize, rye, oats and their products have been removed, and the only restrictionsnow in force on the use of cereals are those.confining the use of wheat, rice and their products to human food. Restrictions on importation are still in force in varying degrees in the case ofwheat, barley, oats, maize, rice, beans,' peas, other forms of pulse and their products.All restrictions on the importation of rye have been removed. Wheat and,Wheaten Flour. It will be necessary to retain control of the irnporta-tion of wheat and wheaten flour until world prices, tonnage and finance enable privateenterprise to maintain adequate supplies at a price sufficiently low to produce thequartern loaf at 9d. or less. This price is approximately 60s. per 480 lbs. for No. 1Manitoba wheat with other varieties at their commercial parity, and it is not antici-pated that the world's markets will reach the point at which general decontrol willbecome possible until the late autumn. With the freeing of wheat from control, acourse for which the assent of the Allies represented on the Inter-Allied WheatExecutive is required, the Royal Commission will no longer trade in bread-stuffs. Itwill be necessary, however, to maintain the Accounts Branch of the Commission forsome time after the introduction of decontrol, in order that the Inter-Allied accountsmay be adjusted and the British accounts closed. Barley. Restrictions on the importation of Californian, Oregon, Washington andChilian barleys have been removed, and it has been decided that restrictions may now be removed in respect of other types of barley, whether for feeding or industrialuse. The Royal Commission now imports only a limited quantity of barley for themanufacture of yeast, and there is no reason to anticipate that private firms willexperience any serious difficulty in obtaining supplies. The Commission, is also ofopinion that complete decontrol of barley will result in a certain quantity of barleyreaching this country from the United States and Canada, and this will be availablefor feeding ^purposes. Barley is not scheduled under the Wheat Executive agreement and decontrol is not complicated by Inter-Allied obligations. . 1 . ' . : Oats. Owing to commitments to the Allies and to the War Office the decontrolof oats cannot be carried out until alternative arrangements, calculated to ensure thenecessary supplies, have been agreed upon. The Italian Government will probablyfeel some apprehension on the proposal to de-schedule oats, but it is anticipated thata guarantee covering the Italian indent for oats in the programme for the currentcereal year will be accepted as satisfactory. The War Office requirements aredecreasing, and there should be no difficulty in meeting the demand either throughthe ordinary trade channels or by way of purchase and shipment on the part of theWheat Commission. Maize. It will be necessary to de-schedule maize before decontrol can beintroduced, and the Allies may take objection to this course. It is doubtful, however,whether decontrol is at present opportune, for not only do shipping difficulties makeit impossible to take full advantage of the supplies of maize in the Argentine, but-the labour position there also tends to reduce the capacity of the ports. Further, theBritish Government has no credit in the Argentine for the purchase of maize whilethe Loan Convention remains unsigned. If imports are decontrolled, it is anticipated that a limited amount of business.will be done and that the margin between the prices in the Argentine and in theUnited Kingdom will enable importers to pay a rate of freight sufficient to attractultimately a considerable volume of tonnage provided that improved labour conditionsmake it possible to load cargoes without excessive delay. The Royal Commission is accordingly approaching ELM. Treasury with a view to ascertaining whether thereis any objection to the' Argentine exchange being thrown on the market. It isdifficult to estimate the effect of decontrol on prices, but there is every reason to anticipate that although prices might advance at first they would fall again to thepresent level, or even lower, in the course of a few months. Rice. The Royal Commission is of opinion that all restrictions on the importa-tion of rice should be removed forthwith. This course would not enable importers to resume normal business immediately as the export of rice from Burma is prohibitedana prices in Saigon and Siam are too high to permit of importation in competition with the present selling prices of the Royal Commission. Importers might be able,however, to import rice from Saigon .and Siam for re-export to France where all restrictions on the importation of rice have been removed or to other european countries which do not hold large stocks of. cheap rice. The Royal Commission holdconsiderable supplies and it will be possible until the end' of the year or longer tomaintain supplies in this country at a price not exceeding the present maximum of id. per pound. Beans, Peas and Pulse. Restrictions on the importation of all kinds of feedingbeans and haricot beans have been removed and the Royal Commission is of opinionthat free importation should also be allowed in respect of all other kinds of beans, peasand pulse. The Maximum (Retail Prices) Order has been suspended, but stocks heldby the Commission are sufficient to- ensure that' prices will not rise above the ratesscheduled in the Order. . . SUPPLIES AND DISTRIBUTION. Bacon.--hi view of the decontrol of bacon and the free licensing of bacon imports,the Bacon Board will cease as from April 2nd to act in an executive capacity. Mr. A.Morrell will also cease to act a3 Director of Bacon Imports. Mr, Morrell and the other imembers of the Bacon Board, however, have consented to assist the Ministry of Food,so far as required, in an advisory capacity, and will be available for consultation fromtime to time. v- : : Major-General Hobbs, as General Director of Bacon Supplies, will take direct responsibility for the allotment of the Ministry's stock. Meetings of the Joint Com-mittee of Importers, Wholesalers aDd. Retailers, will be held as required (as a ruleevery fortnight) to advise the Ministry on questions relating to the disposal of the stocks and the fixing of prices therefor. Meat. The supplies of live stock for last week were short in all.markets, stockbeing held back with a view to the increase in wholesale prices on April 1st. As a consequence the output of frozen meat rose to 11,589 tons. Tea.--It has been decided to allow free importation of tea from all countries afterMarch 31st, to withdraw as from the same date all restrictions on market transactions,and to allow tea to be sold by private sale, for home consumption. The various interests concerned are being consulted on the methods to be adopted for the disposalof tea at public sales. Dried Fruits. Over 30,000 tons of dried fruits have been distributed during thelast six. weeks. ORDKKS UNDER DEFENCE OF THE REALM REGULATIONS. A general licence dated March 27th, .19J 9, under the Beans Peas and Pulse(Retail Prices) Order, 1917, releases these commodities from restrictions as to retail prices and sales under the Order. The Bacon and Ham (Prices) Order, 1919, dated March 28th, 1919, revokes the bacon Ham and Lard (Prices) Order, 1918, and the licences thereunder, and providesmaximum wholesale prices for home-produced bacon and hams, and maximum retail prices for all bacon and hams. A general licence under the Rationing Order, 1918,releases bacon, ham and lard from restrictions under the Order. - A notice dated 1st April revokes the Milk Products (Import Restriction) Order,1918, and the Milk (Products) Returns Order, 1918. Restrictions on the imports ofcondensed milk (other than canned condensed milk), dried milk and sugar of milk aremow removed and returns are no longer required. ENFORCEMENT OF ORDERS. The total number of prosecutions during the week ended March 22nd was 632, of which 604 were successful. ,fn .',\ PART II.-SUMMARY GF THE FOOD POSITION. STOCKS. Stocks of meat and provisions in cold stores and warehouses in the United;Kingdom on March 22nd showed a general decrease as compared with a week before;The fall was most marked in the case of refrigerated meat (6,700 tons), bacon (2,600tons)j canned meat (1,200 tons), cheese (1,800 tons), butter (800 tons), and condensed milk (1,10.0 tons). As to stocks held by the Ministry on the same dates, cerealsshowed a fall of .77,000 tons-, and the approaching measures of decontrol accountedfor the larger depletion of bacon (3,500 tons) and lard (1,100 tons), as compared; withtotal stocks in the United Kingdom. On the other hand there were marked increases.of butter (3,200 tons), cheese (800 tons), and dried fruits (5,500 tons). The oppositemovements of the butter and cheese stocks in the two returns are explained by thefact that large quantities were written off Ministry stocks for distribution early in themonth, and were only gradually removed from the stores and warehouses. Againstthe decreases of stocks in the United Kingdom must be set increases in the quantitiesin transit to the United Kingdom, e.g., in the case of cereals (36,000 tons), refrigeratedmeat (1,300 tons), and butter (2,000 tons), so that the fall of stocks is largely of atemporary character. , The position as regards Ministry stocks and purchases on March 22nd is shownin the following table : ,Stocks held by the Ministry of Food on 22nd March 1919.Commodity. The total imports of the principal foods and feeding-stuffs in the week endedMarch 22nd (116,900 tons) remained at the level of the preceding month, and were still below the average of the first 13 weeks of the calendar year (147,500 tons) or ofthe first 30 weeks of the cereal year (166,400 tons). The outstanding features werethe very large quantities of sugar (46,100 tons) and of meat (16,000 tons) and thefurther drop of cereals to 33,300 tons, which is by far the lowest quantity for any weekiii the current cereal year, and compares with the weekly average of 71,900 tons.Bacon also showed a further slight decrease, the arrivals for the last three weeks being at less than half the rate of preceding months. Of the less bulky commodities, therewere substantial arrivals of tea (7,100 tons), coffee (2,800 tons), cocoa (3,700 tons),and condensed milk (2,000 tons)rbut-.the quantity of cheese fell sharply to 410 tons,while that of butter (120 tons) was negligible.a 7792-113 Total Imports for the first 30 weeks of Cereal Year (ith September to 29th March). * 1918-19. Butchers Meat. There was a further falling off in the supplies of liye stock atmarkets in Great Britain in the week ended March 22nd and estimated total suppliesof home-grown meat fell by 3,500 tons to 13,600 tons. Issues of refrigerated meatrose by 1,800 tons to 9,400 tons, making a total supply of 23,000 tons. The estimatedconsumption of rationed meats in the four weeks ended March 22nd was 24 per cent.below the quantity the Ministry was prepared to issue as rations, and additional supplies to butchers and caterers. It would appear that a certain proportion of consumers or butchers prefer toaccept smaller supplies rather than take a larger proportion of frozen meat. this may disappear Avith the "differentiation of price for. home and imported meat. Theexperience of recent months, with the regular fluctuation in home supplies arisingfrom the advancing scale of prices to farmers on the first of each month, is given inthe following table, which shows that the variations in total consumption have beengoverned by the movements in home supplies, increasing with an increase in home-fed meat and decreasing as that falls off.Week ending. Estimated Home Supplies. Issues of refrigerated meat. Table B (1) continues the four weekly averages of quantities of foodstuffs passing into traders' hands for distribution. It should benoted that the addition of two million demobilised men to the civilian population hasincreased the food requirements of the latter by 4 per cent. In the light of this, thequantity of flour delivered from mills or released from imported supplies now shows a return to the normal rate after the exceptional quantities distributed in.the first twomonths to build up local stocks. The fall in the quantity of bacon allocated for civilian consumption in the four weeks ended March 22nd was due to the check todistribution arising from uncertainty in the trade as to the effects of the removal ofcontrol at the end of the month. The figures for the first 30 weeks of the cereal years 1917-18 and 1918-19 arecompared in the following table : . Milk,-The index showing variations in the quantity o milk carried on theprincipal railways is continued, in Table C (4);: it shows a normal movement ofsupplies, except that the seasonal increase occurred somewhat earlier this year. this applies also to the decrease shown for the week ended March 22nd, which is due to afalling off in the milk forwarded from the principal dairying districts, and; wouldappear to be associated with the opening of the season for the local manufacture of milk products. TABLE D.-STOCKS of the PRINCIPAL FOODS and FEEDING STUFFS in the UNITED KINGDOM. The figures for wheat and flour include stocks in port granaries and warehouses, inland warehouses,mills, and bakers' shops, as well as estimated stocks on farms ; those for barley, oats, beans, and peasinclude stocks in port granaries and warehouses and in mills, in maltsters' hands, and estimated farm stocks ;those for maize, rice, and grain meals include stocks in port granaries and warehouses and in mills. The figures for sugar are stocks in possession of the Sugar Commission ; those for butter, margarine,lard, cheese, condensed milk, meat, and fish include, stocks at ports, in cold stores, and. in importers' andwholesalers' warehouses. The figures for tea, coffee, and cocoa are stocks remaining in bonded warehouses or entered to be,warehoused; and those for oilseeds and oilseed cake include stocks at ports and in the hands of millers,crushers and cake manufacturers.Article.
